title: Can you still feel a limb that's gone? - Joshua W. Pate

multiple-choice.question: What is a common phenomenon experienced by people who have lost a limb?

options.label: A
options.text: They forget the sensation of the missing limb over time.

options.label: B
options.text: They can no longer feel sensations in the remaining limbs.

options.label: C
options.text: They can still feel the missing limb in complete lifelike detail.

options.label: D
options.text: They experience numbness in the remaining limbs.

multiple-choice.question: What is suggested by the fact that people born without a limb can still feel a phantom limb?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain develops a map of the body through experience.

options.label: B
options.text: We are born with at least the beginnings of a map of the body in our brains.

options.label: C
options.text: Phantom limbs are only experienced by people who have had a limb amputated.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain is unable to adapt to the loss of a limb.

multiple-choice.question: What sets phantom limbs that appear after amputation apart from their flesh and blood predecessors?

options.label: C
options.text: The vast majority of them are painful.

multiple-choice.question: What carries sensory input from the limbs to the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Neural pathways through the spinal cord.

options.label: C
options.text: The dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to severed nerve endings at the site of an amputation?

options.label: C
options.text: They thicken and become more sensitive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the somatosensory cortex?

options.label: C
options.text: To process sensory signals from the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the cortical homunculus?

options.label: A
options.text: A model of the human brain.

options.label: B
options.text: A model of the human body with proportions based on the size of each body part's representation in the cortex.

multiple-choice.question: What can lead to phantom pain?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in cortical representation of a body part.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in cortical representation of a body part.

options.label: C
options.text: A lack of sensory input from a body part.

options.label: D
options.text: A loss of inhibitory control in the dorsal horn.

multiple-choice.question: What is mirror box therapy used to treat?
What is a potential benefit of further research into phantom limbs?

options.label: A
options.text: A deeper understanding of the subjective nature of reality.

options.label: C
options.text: A new treatment for muscle weakness.

options.label: D
options.text: A better understanding of the visual system.

title: Everything you need to know to read "The Canterbury Tales" - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: In "The Canterbury Tales," what is the name of the archbishop whose shrine the pilgrims are visiting?
What is the name of the inn where the characters in "The Canterbury Tales" first meet?
What is the name of the language in which "The Canterbury Tales" is written?
What event in 1066 contributed to the evolution of Middle English?
What is the name of the symbol in Middle English that denotes the y, j, or gh sound?
What is the social system that divided Medieval society into different classes?
What is the occupation of the majority of Chaucer's life?
What is the name of the war that Chaucer was involved in during his lifetime?
What is the approximate number of lines in "The Canterbury Tales"?
How many stories was each pilgrim supposed to tell, according to the prologue?

title: The "End Of History" Illusion - Bence Nanay

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon, documented by three psychologists in 2013, refers to our inability to predict personal change in ourselves?
The term "The End of History Illusion" is inspired by the work of which political scientist?
How many participants were recruited for the study on "The End of History Illusion"?
What was the age range of the participants in the study?
According to the study, what did the researchers find when comparing the predicted changes to the reported changes across different age groups?
What is one consequence of the "End of History Illusion" in our personal lives?

options.label: A
options.text: We tend to underinvest in future choices

options.label: B
options.text: We tend to overinvest in future choices based on present preferences

options.label: C
options.text: We tend to make impulsive decisions

options.label: D
options.text: We tend to avoid long-term commitments

multiple-choice.question: On average, how much more are people willing to pay to see their current favorite musician ten years in the future compared to their favorite musician from ten years ago?
According to the transcript, what is one potential problem with not having the "End of History Illusion"?

options.label: A
options.text: We would be too cautious in our decision-making

options.label: B
options.text: We would be too impulsive in our decision-making

options.label: C
options.text: We would have difficulty making long-term plans

options.label: D
options.text: We would be too confident in our predictions

multiple-choice.question: What is one implication of the "End of History Illusion" for our understanding of the wider world?

options.label: A
options.text: We should assume that the current state of the world will continue indefinitely

options.label: B
options.text: We should be aware that the world can change, sometimes for the better

options.label: C
options.text: We should be pessimistic about the future

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one potential source of comfort in recognizing that our own historical moment is not the "end of history"?

options.label: C
options.text: The stability of the current state of the world

title: Why should you read Edgar Allan Poe? - Scott Peeples

multiple-choice.question: What are the two cardinal rules for the short story form identified by Edgar Allan Poe as a literary critic?

options.label: A
options.text: It must be written in the first person and have a happy ending.

options.label: B
options.text: It must be short enough to read in one sitting and have a complex plot.

options.label: C
options.text: It must be short enough to read in one sitting, and every word must contribute to its purpose.

options.label: D
options.text: It must have a clear moral message and be free of violence and horror.

multiple-choice.question: What does Poe call the intense and singular experience that his stories aim to create in the reader?

options.label: D
options.text: The darkness of the human mind

multiple-choice.question: What is the true darkness that Poe's stories often explore, rather than supernatural elements?

options.label: A
options.text: The human mind and its propensity for self-destruction

options.label: C
options.text: The power of love and grief

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of clear moral messages

multiple-choice.question: In "The Tell-Tale Heart," what is juxtaposed with the killer's tender empathy towards the victim?
What literary device does Poe pioneer in his stories, making readers active participants in the narrative?
What genre of story did Poe invent with "The Murders in the Rue Morgue"?
What is the name of the original armchair detective created by Poe?
What is the theme of Poe's most famous poem, "The Raven"?
What was the cause of death of Poe's mother and wife?
When did much of Poe's fame come, and what was it based on?

options.label: A
options.text: During his lifetime, based on his original works

options.label: B
options.text: Posthumously, based on loose adaptations of his work

options.label: C
options.text: During his lifetime, based on his literary criticism

options.label: D
options.text: Posthumously, based on his poetry alone

title: What would happen if every human suddenly disappeared? - Dan Kwartler

multiple-choice.question: What do most scientists believe humanity has left on Earth's geological record?

options.label: D
options.text: They are destroyed by natural disasters

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They are taken over by animals

options.label: D
options.text: They are taken over by animals

multiple-choice.question: What happens to most houses' supporting beams within 75 years after humans disappear?

options.label: B
options.text: They are destroyed by natural disasters

options.label: D
options.text: They are taken over by animals

Which animals are unable to survive without humans, except for a handful of resourceful ones?
How long does it take for the plant cycle to remove the last traces of lead left by the Industrial Revolution from Earth's soil?
How long does Mt. Rushmore, carved in unyielding granite, survive after humans disappear?

title: How do cigarettes affect the body? - Krishna Sudhir

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of chemical substances in cigarette smoke that come into contact with the body's tissues?
What is the primary function of the cilia in the airways and lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: To facilitate the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the toxic gas that binds to hemoglobin and displaces oxygen in the blood?
What is the approximate time it takes for nicotine to reach the brain after inhalation?
What is the name of the neurotransmitter released in response to nicotine, which creates pleasurable sensations?
What is the estimated proportion of cancer deaths in the United States caused by smoking?
What is the approximate time it takes for heart rate and blood pressure to return to normal after quitting smoking?
What is the primary function of nicotine replacement therapy?

options.label: B
options.text: To stimulate nicotine receptors in the brain and prevent withdrawal symptoms

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated time it takes for the risk of developing fatal lung cancer to decrease by 50% after quitting smoking?
What is the estimated time it takes for the likelihood of developing coronary heart disease to become similar to that of a non-smoker after quitting smoking?

title: How the Normans changed the history of Europe - Mark Robinson

multiple-choice.question: In what year did 7000 Norman infantry and knights sail across the English Channel to conquer England?
What was the name given to the Viking invaders by the French locals, named for the direction they came from?
Who negotiated peace with the Viking leader Rollo in 911, granting him a stretch of land along France's northern coast?

options.label: B
options.text: Charles, the king of the Franks

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the 70-meter-long tapestry that immortalized the Battle of Hastings?
What was the name of the massive survey conducted by William the Conqueror to record the population and ownership of every piece of land in England?
What language became the language of the new royal court after the Norman conquest of England?
What was the name of the kingdom formed in 1130 by the Normans in Southern Italy?
Who was the king of the Kingdom of Sicily who promoted multicultural tolerance and compiled the world's geographical knowledge in The Book of Roger?
What was the name of the book compiled by Roger II that contained maps of the known world that would remain the most accurate available for 300 years?
Why did the Normans eventually disappear as a distinct group?

options.label: B
options.text: They were assimilated into the societies they conquered

options.label: C
options.text: They returned to their Viking roots

options.label: D
options.text: They were wiped out by disease

title: How can you change someone's mind? (hint: facts aren't always enough) - Hugo Mercier

multiple-choice.question: At the dinner party, who is Linda looking at?
What was the outcome of the 2005 study by Brendan Nyhan and Jason Reifler regarding American attitudes on the justifications for the Iraq War?

options.label: A
options.text: Many participants changed their minds after reading the news article

options.label: B
options.text: Many participants remained neutral after reading the news article

options.label: C
options.text: Many participants continued to believe that WMDs had been found despite the news article

options.label: D
options.text: Many participants became less convinced of their original views

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what makes arguments more convincing?

options.label: B
options.text: Taking into account what the audience believes, who they trust, and what they value

title: How exactly does binary code work? - José Américo N L F Freitas

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason computers use binary code?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most complex form of data storage.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a reliable way of storing data.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the only way to store data.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the fastest way to store data.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of transistors in a computer's main memory?

options.label: B
options.text: To switch between high or low voltage levels.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide power to the computer.

multiple-choice.question: How do computers interpret binary sequences?

options.label: A
options.text: Each sequence has a pre-determined meaning.

options.label: B
options.text: Each sequence is interpreted based on the context.

options.label: C
options.text: Each sequence is interpreted based on a fixed set of rules.

multiple-choice.question: What is the basis for binary number notation?

options.label: A
options.text: Each position is based on 10 raised to some power.

options.label: B
options.text: Each position is based on 2 raised to some power.

options.label: C
options.text: Each position is based on a random number.

options.label: D
options.text: Each position is based on a fixed number.

multiple-choice.question: What is the standard rule for interpreting letters in binary code?
How are pixels represented in color images?

options.label: B
options.text: By three binary sequences corresponding to primary colors.

options.label: C
options.text: By a combination of binary and decimal sequences.

options.label: D
options.text: By a random sequence of numbers.

multiple-choice.question: What technique is used to store sound in binary code?
What is the purpose of run-length encoding?

options.label: A
options.text: To compress data by recording repeated values.

options.label: B
options.text: To decompress data by expanding repeated values.

options.label: C
options.text: To encrypt data for secure transmission.

options.label: D
options.text: To decrypt data for secure transmission.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential alternative to binary computers?
Why have alternative computing methods not replaced binary code?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too complex to implement.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too expensive to produce.

options.label: C
options.text: They have not provided as much physical stability for data storage and transmission.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not compatible with existing technology.

multiple-choice.question: Where are the coldest materials in the world typically found?

options.label: A

title: The physics of roller coasters

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not being supported by anything

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are experiencing a strong normal force

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are experiencing a strong frictional force

multiple-choice.question: What type of energy is converted into heat energy when a roller coaster uses frictional brakes?
What is the primary mechanism by which eddy current brakes slow down a roller coaster train?
What law explains why conductors like metal fins create a current that opposes a change in magnetic field?

options.label: C
options.text: They do not wear out as quickly

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the winch in a hydraulic launch system?

options.label: C
options.text: To lift the train to the top of the first hill

title: Are there universal expressions of emotion? - Sophie Zadeh

multiple-choice.question: According to Charles Darwin, what is a common human feature across cultures?
Who claimed that certain affects, including emotional states and facial expressions, are universal?
What method did Paul Ekman use to test the universality of emotional expressions?

options.label: B
options.text: Examining hundreds of hours of film footage of remote tribes

options.label: C
options.text: Analyzing facial expressions in people born blind

options.label: D
options.text: Comparing facial expressions between humans and non-human mammals

options.label: A
options.text: They were unable to match photos of different facial expressions with stories

options.label: B
options.text: They were able to correctly match photos of different facial expressions with stories

options.label: D
options.text: They had completely different emotional expressions

options.label: A
options.text: They displayed different emotional expressions than sighted people

options.label: B
options.text: They displayed the same emotional expressions as sighted people

multiple-choice.question: How many core expressions did Paul Ekman identify in the 1960s?

options.label: A
options.text: By letting our eyes absorb less light

options.label: B
options.text: By letting our lungs take in less air

options.label: C

options.label: C

title: How one scientist averted a national health crisis - Andrea Tone

multiple-choice.question: Where did Frances Oldham Kelsey earn her undergraduate and master's degrees in pharmacology?

Why was thalidomide a popular remedy for pregnant women?

options.label: D
options.text: Its ability to reduce workplace stress

multiple-choice.question: What did Kelsey's earlier animal-based research demonstrate?

options.text: The placental barrier shielded a fetus from harm

options.label: B
options.text: Drugs could not pass from mother to fetus through the placenta

options.label: C
options.text: Drugs could pass from mother to fetus through the placenta

options.label: D
options.text: Thalidomide was safe for pregnant women

multiple-choice.question: Why did Kelsey reject Merrell's initial application to sell thalidomide?

options.text: The data on thalidomide's absorption and toxicity was inadequate

options.label: B
options.text: The data on thalidomide's safety was satisfactory

options.label: C
options.text: The FDA did not classify thalidomide as a safe drug

options.label: B
options.text: Mild birth defects, including minor physical abnormalities

multiple-choice.question: When was thalidomide pulled from the German market?

options.label: C
options.text: A special award for her heroism in preventing the approval of thalidomide

options.label: D
options.text: The award is not specified in the transcript

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Kelsey's actions regarding thalidomide?

options.label: A
options.text: Congress passed laws that expanded the FDA's authority and toughened requirements for new drug applications

options.label: B
options.text: The FDA reduced its authority and relaxed requirements for new drug applications

options.label: C
options.text: The pharmaceutical industry self-regulated and improved its safety standards

options.label: D
options.text: There was no significant impact on the FDA or pharmaceutical industry

multiple-choice.question: What was Frances Kelsey's legacy in the field of medicine?

options.text: She prioritized opinions over facts and shortcuts over patience

options.label: B
options.text: She made evidence-based medicine the foundation of reforms that continue to protect people today

options.label: C
options.text: She only focused on the safety of thalidomide and did not contribute to broader reforms

options.text: She did not have a significant impact on the field of medicine

options.label: D
options.text: To adapt to the lunar environment

multiple-choice.question: What is the moon's gravity compared to the Earth's?
What is one of the potential benefits of a radio telescope on the moon's far side?

options.label: B
options.text: Observing the cosmos, shielded from the Earth's electromagnetic interference

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential economic benefits of a moon base?

options.label: A
options.text: Mining minerals such as silicon, aluminum, and magnesium

multiple-choice.question: What is the proposed Deep Space Gateway?

options.label: B
options.text: A space station in lunar orbit

options.label: C
options.text: A launching platform for future missions to the moon

options.label: D
options.text: A proposal to launch future missions from lunar orbit

multiple-choice.question: Which space agencies and entities are expressing interest in the moon camp project?

options.label: B
options.text: Only NASA and the European Space Agency

options.label: C
options.text: Europe, Russia, China, and the US, as well as private companies

title: Can you solve the penniless pilgrim riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: How many blocks does the town of Duonia consist of?
What is the initial tax amount when you arrive in Duonia?
What happens to the tax when you walk east in Duonia?
What is the effect of walking a block north on the total tax bill?
What is the result of walking a counterclockwise loop around a single block in Duonia?

options.label: C
options.text: Your tax bill remains the same

multiple-choice.question: Why does walking a counterclockwise loop earn you one silver?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the taxes for opposite directions balance each other out

options.label: B
options.text: Because any tax doubled, plus two, halved, and minus two, always ends up one smaller than it started

options.label: D
options.text: Because the city has a special promotion

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of walking four counterclockwise loops on your initial tax bill of 4 silver?
Why can't you simply walk four counterclockwise loops to reduce your tax bill to zero?

options.label: B
options.text: Because you can't walk the same block twice

options.label: C
options.text: Because the city has a rule against it

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's not possible to walk counterclockwise

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of walking one large counterclockwise loop through the city?
What lesson do you learn from your pilgrimage in Duonia?

options.label: A
options.text: That the shortest route is always the best

options.label: B
options.text: That an indirect route is sometimes the best way to reach your destination

options.label: C
options.text: That walking counterclockwise is always better

title: Why is it so hard to cure ALS? - Fernando Vieira

multiple-choice.question: What was the age of Stephen Hawking when he was diagnosed with ALS?
What percentage of ALS cases are hereditary?
What is the typical life expectancy after diagnosis for most people with ALS?
Which of the following statements is true about Stephen Hawking's case of ALS?

options.label: B
options.text: His ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses was impaired

options.label: C
options.text: His case was unusual because of his impaired cognition

options.label: D
options.text: His ability to learn, think, and perceive with his senses remained intact

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of people diagnosed with ALS annually?
What is the primary function of upper motor neurons in a healthy body?

options.label: A
options.text: To transmit messages from the spinal cord to the brain

options.label: B
options.text: To transmit messages from the brain to the lower motor neurons

options.label: C
options.text: To transmit messages from the lower motor neurons to the muscles

options.label: D
options.text: To transmit messages from the muscles to the lower motor neurons

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the muscles when motor neurons degenerate in ALS?
What is one prevailing idea about the cause of ALS?

options.label: A
options.text: That certain proteins inside the motor neurons are folding correctly

options.label: B
options.text: That certain proteins inside the motor neurons aren't folding correctly and are forming clumps

options.label: C
options.text: That ALS is caused by a single genetic mutation

options.label: D
options.text: That ALS is caused by a virus

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential role of defective immune cells in ALS?

options.label: A
options.text: They may help to repair damaged motor neurons

options.label: B
options.text: They may play a role in killing motor neurons

options.label: C
options.text: They may have no impact on the disease

options.label: D
options.text: They may help to slow the advancement of the disease

multiple-choice.question: What types of therapies are currently being developed to treat ALS?

options.label: D
options.text: New drugs, new stem cell therapies, and new gene therapies

title: The journey to Pluto, the farthest world ever explored - Alan Stern

multiple-choice.question: How far away was the New Horizons spacecraft from Earth on July 4, 2015?

Why did astronomers want to explore Pluto before 2020?

options.label: C
options.text: Because Pluto's surface would become hotter

options.label: D
options.text: Because Pluto's surface would become brighter

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.text: Because it was too slow to orbit Pluto

title: Why do we sweat? - John Murnan

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of sweat in the human body?

options.label: B
options.text: To produce energy for the muscles

options.text: To cool down the body through evaporation

Where do temperature sensors detect excess heat being produced by muscle cells?

options.label: B

options.text: Because spices stimulate the immune system

options.label: D

title: How does hibernation work? - Sheena Faherty

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason animals hibernate in the wild?

options.label: B
options.text: To conserve energy and survive harsh winter months

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following animals is known to give birth and lactate while hibernating?
How do hibernating animals' heartbeats typically change during hibernation?

options.label: A
options.text: They increase to 150% of their original speed

options.label: B
options.text: They remain the same as their original speed

options.label: C
options.text: They slow to about 1 to 3% of their original speed

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a hibernating animal's brain activity during hibernation?

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same as when the animal is awake

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the regular bouts of reduced metabolic rate and body temperature that occur during hibernation?
Why do researchers believe that studying hibernating animals could lead to better treatments for certain human conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Because hibernating animals are immune to all diseases

options.label: B
options.text: Because hibernating animals have unique physiological adaptations that could inform human medicine

options.label: C
options.text: Because hibernating animals are able to live forever

options.label: D
options.text: Because hibernating animals are able to cure diseases

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a potential benefit of studying hibernating animals for human health?

options.label: A
options.text: Understanding how to slow down aging

options.label: C
options.text: Understanding how to protect the brain during a stroke

options.label: D
options.text: Understanding how to strengthen the immune system

multiple-choice.question: What do researchers believe controls hibernation in animals?

options.label: A
options.text: Environmental factors such as temperature and humidity

options.label: B
options.text: Genes that turn off and on in unique patterns throughout the year

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new treatments for human diseases

options.label: B
options.text: To improve our understanding of animal behavior

options.label: C
options.text: To make human hibernation a real possibility

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new technologies for space exploration

title: How do we study living brains? - John Borghi and Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in studying the human brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain is too small to study

options.label: B
options.text: The brain is too complex to understand

options.label: C
options.text: The brain is shielded by a thick skull and layers of protective tissue

options.label: D
options.text: The brain is not sophisticated enough to study itself

multiple-choice.question: What does EEG (electroencephalography) measure in the brain?
What is a limitation of EEG in studying the brain?

options.label: C
options.text: It is hard to determine exactly where any particular pattern originates

multiple-choice.question: What does fMRI (functional magnetic resonance imaging) measure in the brain?
How does fMRI pinpoint differences in brain activity?
What is the third technique mentioned in the transcript for studying the brain?
What does PET measure in the brain?
What is a limitation of PET in studying the brain?

options.label: C
options.text: It has the lowest time resolution of all

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a research question that could be studied using these techniques?

options.label: A
options.text: How does the brain process visual information?

options.label: B
options.text: How does the brain understand language?

options.label: D
options.text: How does the brain control movement?

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential future advancement in brain imaging technology?

options.label: B
options.text: Distinguishing the activity of individual neurons
